abstract: Senate panel approves legislation rewriting the 2002 No Child Left Behind education law that would greatly reduce the federal government's role in overseeing public schools; lawmakers were prompted to act after becoming irritated that the Obama administration had begun to offer states waivers to the law's key provisions.
snippet: Anger over the Obama administration’s No Child Left Behind waiver plan prodded lawmakers to approve a bill that would greatly reduce Washington’s role in overseeing public schools.
lead_paragraph: Anger over the Obama administration’s No Child Left Behind waiver plan prodded lawmakers to approve a bill that would greatly reduce Washington’s role in overseeing public schools.

headline.main: Senate Panel Approves Bill That Rewrites Education Law
headline.print_headline: Senate Panel Approves Bill That Rewrites Education Law
headline.seo: Senate Panel Advances ‘No Child’ Law Rewrite
